work.p: "My task," "L of G's Purport," "Death dogs my steps," the first three of four poems on this page, were later fused and published as "L of G's Purport."
The fourth poem, "For us two, reader dear" was published separately at the end of a prose piece in "Goodbye My Fancy.

notesStmt.note: This page was likely composed about 1891, the year of publication of "L. of G.'s Purport" and "For us two, reader dear."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: My Task
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.head: My Task
lg.l:
Begun in ripen'd youth and steadily
pursued, throughout

Wandering, peering, dallying with all—war,
peace, day and night absorbing,
Never even for one brief hour abandoning my task,
I end it here in poverty, sickness, and old age.

lg.head: L of G's Purport.
lg.l:
Not to exclude or demarcate, or pick out
evils from their formidable masses (even
to expose them,)

But to add, fuse, complete, extend—and cel-
ebrate the immortal and
the
the
good.

lg.head: Death dogs my steps
lg.l: I sing of life, yet mind me well of death;

To-day shadowy Death dogs my steps, and has for years—my
seated shape,
Draws sometimes close to me, as face to face.

lg.head: For us two, reader dear.
lg.l: Simple, spontaneous, curious, two souls interchanging

With the original testimony for us two continued
on to the last.
